sense.def: a polite way of speaking to a woman
dictionaryExamples: Can I help you, ma’am?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ma'am, I am sorry to say that I will not be able to attend tomor[r]ow's English class.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: a piece of equipment with several moving parts which uses power to do a particular type of work
dictionaryExamples: a washing machine
a coffee machine
Eggs are sorted into different sizes by machine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell the washing machine. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: machines, often large machines
dictionaryExamples: industrial/farm machinery
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many pieces of machinery used in the production line do not necessarily have to be functioning the entire time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: angry
dictionaryExamples: Are you still mad at me?
Kerry got really mad with Richard for not doing washing the dishes.
He's always complaining and it makes me so mad.
My little brother drives me mad sometimes!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm not mad because you missed my party. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to love someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They only met a month ago but he's mad about her.
Jo's mad about skiing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know, I hate pink, but my mother is really mad about pink. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: mentally ill
dictionaryExamples: I think I must be going mad.
He went mad with grief.
Do I look like some mad old woman in this hat?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The movie was about [a] guy that was mad. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a lot
dictionaryExamples: The band practiced like mad before their first concert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was raining like mad, so we were wet to the skin. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a formal and polite way of speaking to a woman
dictionaryExamples: Can I help you, madam?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [An] old woman came in the shop and quietly put my suitcase near to me and she said "Excuse me, Madam, it's your suitcase. I saw somebody t[ake] it. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a way of beginning a formal letter to a woman whose name you do not know
dictionaryExamples: Dear Madam, I am writing to inform you...
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir or Madam, With reference to your newspaper report of 17th July, I am writing to correct some points in this report. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a thin book published every week or month, that has shiny, colorful pages with articles and pictures
dictionaryExamples: She has written articles for several women's magazines.
a fashion/celebrity magazine
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the party, Maria, Paula, Marissa and I read magazines, talked about boys [and] played games. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: special powers that can make things happen that seem impossible
dictionaryExamples: Do you believe in magic?
As if by magic, the car changes into a boat when it hits the water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I liked very much the book about magic. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: skillful  tricks that are done to entertain people, such as making things appear and disappear and pretending to cut someone in half
dictionaryExamples: He's a comedian who also does magic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a magic show every day, I think you must [go] there once. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a quality that makes something or someone seem special or exciting
dictionaryExamples: No one could fail to enjoy the magic of this wonderful city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But everyone [was] thinking of the elections and couldn't feel the "magic" of Christmas Day... First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: relating to skillful tricks done to entertain people
dictionaryExamples: a magic show
I'll show you a magic trick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that a magician showed us a lot of magic tricks. Key English Test; A2; Gujarati

sense.def: with special powers that make impossible things happen
dictionaryExamples: The witch put a magic spell on the prince and turned him into a frog.
There's no magic solution to the problem.

sense.def: special and exciting
dictionaryExamples: It was a magical night.
The setting for the concert was quite magical.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you should go to Cracow - [a] beautiful, old city with original, historical monuments, works of art and many cafes and jazz clubs with [a] magical atmosphere. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: with special powers that make impossible things happen
dictionaryExamples: magical powers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We cherish the belief in a magical force outside ourselves, which sooner or later will deliver us these dreams. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: having  a thin coat of material that is able to electrically store information
dictionaryExamples: Your account information is on the magnetic strip on the back of your debit card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: 75% of the staff suggested that the keys be changed for magnetic keys, that don't need to be left in reception when the client go[es] out. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: having a character that attracts people to you
dictionaryExamples: He has a magnetic personality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ivan has a magnetic personality, which draws people to him. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: able to attract and stick to iron or steel objects or cause this to happen
dictionaryExamples: This note pad is magnetic, so you can stick it on your refrigerator.
a magnetic lock
a magnetic field
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The glass shutter doors are broken and the door latch is also not working anymore since the magnetic stopper came unstuck during transit. International English Language Testing System; C2; Telugu

sense.def: very good or very  beautiful
dictionaryExamples: a magnificent view
They live in a magnificent old house.
He gave a magnificent performance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next, we went to [a] for[e]st. [I]n the middle was a lake and the sight was magnificent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: extremely well
dictionaryExamples: I thought she coped magnificently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This small drawback did not affect either the dance display or the horse show, which were both performed magnificently. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: letters and packages that are delivered to homes, places of  work, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Did the mail come yet? / Was the mail delivered yet?
She spent the morning reading and answering her mail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I check my mail every day and I hope[d] to have a letter from you sooner than this. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the public system by which letters and packages are sent and delivered
dictionaryExamples: You will be sent your test results by mail.
A package for you came in the mail today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Carol, I've forgot[ten] my palm top [at] your house, you can  send [it to] me by mail. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: e-mail
dictionaryExamples: I just want to check my mail before I turn off the computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came back home from school, I immediately checked my hotmail account [to] see if any mail from my friend [had] arrived. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: to send a letter or package by mail
dictionaryExamples: Did you remember to mail me that letter  / to mail that letter to me?
Please sign the form and mail it to the address below.
I have to get to the post office and mail (off) this package.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I already asked a friend of mine to pass me the notes and to mail me the homework. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: most important or largest
dictionaryExamples: The main airport is 15 miles from the capital.
One of the main reasons I came to England was to study the language.
You'll find the main points of my proposal in the report.
Our main goal/objective is to improve the company's productivity.
The main problem in the health care system is lack of resources.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, the main reason, I must admit, was that I wanted to meet new people, make new friends and the college is the best place for meeting interesting people. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the most important fact in a situation
dictionaryExamples: You're happy and that's the main thing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main thing is to be happy and to love yourself. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the largest or most important part of a meal
dictionaryExamples: I had salmon for my main course.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main course could be fish or meat with vegetables. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: mostly or to a large degree
dictionaryExamples: The waitresses are mainly French.
They argued that the tax will mainly benefit the rich.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I often wear jeans, mainly blue jeans. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: considered normal, and having or using ideas, beliefs, etc. which are accepted by most people
dictionaryExamples: This is the director's first mainstream Hollywood film.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The media source and its credibility play a major role in determining the objectivity and realistic portrayal although there ha[ve] been cases where even mainstream publications have participated in manipulative alterations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to make a situation or activity continue in the same way
dictionaryExamples: The army has been brought in to maintain order in the region.
We have standards to maintain.
The two countries have maintained close links over the years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If this not is possible he should work less [hard] in order to maintain his health[.] First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to keep a road, machine, building, etc. in good condition
dictionaryExamples: A large house costs a lot to maintain.
The roads generally are very poorly maintained.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to my education and my experience in maintaining machines, I am sure that I can do a good job in your club. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to say that you are certain something is true
dictionaryExamples: She maintains that she’s being criticized simply for telling the truth.
Dunn has always maintained his innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, sceptics maintain that the lack of facilities and jobs leads to the countryside being "abandoned." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the work needed to keep a road, building, machine, etc. in good condition
dictionaryExamples: car maintenance classes
Old houses require too much maintenance.
I need a garden that's very low maintenance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many people can't afford to have a car as maintenance is very expensive. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: more important, bigger or more serious than others of the same type
dictionaryExamples: This is a major problem for people in this region.
Sugar is a major cause of tooth decay.
America has played a major role in the peace process.
Citrus fruits are a major source of vitamin C.
There has been a major change in attitudes recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some major changes are really necessary. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the most important subject that a college or university student studies, or a student studying that subject
dictionaryExamples: What's your major?
Diane's an English major.
I can speak English well as my major is English literature. (570170; First Certificate in English; Korea, South; B2 VANTAGE; 1999; Korean; Fail)

sense.def: to study something as your main subject in college or a university
dictionaryExamples: She majored in earth sciences at Arizona State.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have majored in English for four years. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: more than half of a group of people or things
dictionaryExamples: The majority of our employees have university degrees.
A large majority of people approve of the death sentence.
The vast majority of smokers claim they would like to quit.
In Britain women are in the majority.
the majority decision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However the majority of the teachers found that buying movies was not a good idea. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to produce or create something
dictionaryExamples: Shall I make some coffee?
He made us some lunch.
She makes all her own clothes.
He works for a company that makes garden furniture.
John Huston made some great films.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can make a quick snack, for example a sandwich. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: to be produced from a substance or material
dictionaryExamples: Butter is made from milk.
There were bowls made of pure gold.
They make furniture out of steel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is made of gold. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: to perform an action
dictionaryExamples: I must make a telephone call.
Have you made a doctor's appointment?
Have you made a decision about your job yet?
Someone's made a mistake.
Can I make a suggestion?
He's not making any effort.
She made a short speech.
Shall we make a start on the work?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I made a good choice. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to take action so that you are certain that something happens
dictionaryExamples: I'll just make sure I've turned the oven off.
Make sure you're home by midnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So please make sure that you we[ar] old clothes. Key English Test; A2; Albanian

sense.def: to cause something to happen or cause a particular state
dictionaryExamples: What made you change your mind?
He really makes me laugh.
This photograph makes me look about 80!
It makes me so angry when he says that.
This heat makes me very tired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's so funny and it makes me laugh. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: to force someone or something to do something
dictionaryExamples: I made him clean his room.
You can't make him go if he doesn't want to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could make him wait a little. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: make up your mind or make your mind up

sense.def: to make a decision
dictionaryExamples: I haven't made up my mind whether to apply for the job yet.
They couldn't make their minds up about where to go on holiday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The place was so dirty that I made up my mind to change it by buy[ing] something useful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to manage to arrive at a place
dictionaryExamples: I'm afraid I can't make the meeting this afternoon.
She made it to  the airport just in time to catch her plane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Respected Madam, I'm sorry that I can't make it to the English class tomorrow as I have a high temperature. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to show with your face that you do not like someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Joe made a face when he saw what was for lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Making a face, I slapped my forehead. Preliminary English Test; B1; Assamese

sense.def: to begin to know and like someone
dictionaryExamples: He finds it difficult to make friends.
He's made friends with a boy in his class called Alex.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I didn't know anyone in this club, I immediately made friends with Maria and Rosaria. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to earn
dictionaryExamples: She makes around  $80,000 a year as a doctor.
How do you make a living as a painter?
Both companies  have made huge profits/losses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The truth is that our grandparents worked very hard to make a living. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to put sheets and covers on a bed or to make the sheets and covers on a bed neat
dictionaryExamples: Did you make the bed?
The kids don't always have time to make their beds before school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Driving through the mountains we didn't reach the cabin until late at night.  So we just made the beds and went off to sleep. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to take full advantage of something because it may not last long
dictionaryExamples: We should make the most of this good weather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember, always try to make the most of your life. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to try to be positive about a situation you do not like but cannot change
dictionaryExamples: Our hotel room is pretty small, but we'll just have to make the best of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately I don't have very much spare time so we will have to arrange it carefully in order to make the best of your time in London. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to improve a situation (a lot)
dictionaryExamples: Exercise can make a big difference to your health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wouldn't make a big difference in my life, but it would be good. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a situation more difficult, unpleasant, etc.
dictionaryExamples: To make matters worse, our car broke down!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make matters worse, the newspaper said they only played for thirty-five minutes. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to make someone look stupid intentionally
dictionaryExamples: She was always trying to make a fool out of me in front of my friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He thought I had tried to make a fool of him but no, I was really desperate to get him as my boyfriend. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to behave in a silly or embarrassing way
dictionaryExamples: I got very excited  and made a fool of myself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to leave that shop in full embarrassment and I also made a fool of myself. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to make a joke about someone or something in an unkind way
dictionaryExamples: The other children at school used to make fun of his hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't want to tell other people because I didn't want them to make fun of me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to have a meaning or reason that you can understand
dictionaryExamples: He's written me this note but it doesn't make any sense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All these words might not make sense but this is the story of how we felt. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be a good thing to do
dictionaryExamples: It makes sense to buy now while prices are low.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore it make[s] sense to use the innovation[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to leave enough time to do something although you are busy
dictionaryExamples: You have to make time to do your homework.
He never made enough time for family life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm terribly sorry for not being able to make time to pick you up when you arrive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to have the necessary qualities to become something
dictionaryExamples: He would make a really good dad.
I wouldn't make a very good lawyer.
It's a very exciting story - it would make a great film.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is why I think I would make a good judge. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to be successful
dictionaryExamples: Very few actors actually make it.
Fe made it big in the music business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People who belong to this social [group] are much more determined to "make it" in life. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: to have just enough money to pay for the things that you need
dictionaryExamples: I had to get a second job just to make ends meet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most students support themselves and barely make ends meet every month. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to behave in a relaxed way in a place, as if it was your own home
dictionaryExamples: Take off your coat and make yourself at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please relax and make yourself at home and help yourself. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to write down information about something
dictionaryExamples: Let me make a note of your phone number.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After talking to other members, I have made a note of the main problems they considered the most urgent to be solved. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to say something to someone in a way that they understand
dictionaryExamples: I had a little difficulty making myself understood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: (Find enclosed a paper slip on which I have written a destination, number of tickets, etc., in the German language - use it just in case you can't make yourselves understood.) Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

blocks.phrase: to make a long story short

sense.def: to mention only the final result or point of something without going into other details
dictionaryExamples: To make a long story short, he never played baseball again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make a long story short, my mother turned out to be an understanding person. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to use something that is less good than you would like
dictionaryExamples: If we can't get a bigger room we'll have to make do with this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Very calmly, he said "I am not going to put up with this. You might say that I am being too emotional, overreacting, whatever. But I will not come back until my piano has been returned.  And let me make very clear that I will not make do with another instrument." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to talk or behave as if you do not think a problem is serious
dictionaryExamples: I just laughed and tried to make light of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They project an optimistic image and make light of the troubles in life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to remember that someone has a disadvantage which is not their fault when you are judging their behavior or work
dictionaryExamples: They made allowances for the fact that he was ill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would say Mr. Stevens is a victim of his sense of duty, which makes him think of marriage as a traitor's act, but I don't know to what extent we should make allowances for his strong convictions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If something makes your blood run cold, it frightens you very much.
dictionaryExamples: I heard a tapping on the window which made my blood run cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This thought scared me and made my blood run cold. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to make you extremely angry
dictionaryExamples: The way they have treated those people makes my blood boil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paul said something repulsive, with a cold light in his eyes, and it made her blood boil. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to make someone very happy
dictionaryExamples: Seeing those little kids having so much fun just made my day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for returning [my] lost diary; you have made my day! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to talk or behave as if you do not think a problem is serious
dictionaryExamples: I just laughed and tried to make light of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They project an optimistic image and make light of the troubles in life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to become famous or respected by a lot of people
dictionaryExamples: He's been trying to make a name for himself in the music business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, only [a] few sportsmen and sportswomen manage to make a name for themselves and get to the top. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to have a strong effect on other people
dictionaryExamples: The new police chief has really made his presence felt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before long a local bicycle gang was formed which would ride all over the village, through fields and gardens, making our presence felt. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to suddenly run fast in order to escape from somewhere
dictionaryExamples: When he saw the open door, he made a run for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anna and Tom decided to make a run for it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to cause problems by asking difficult questions or criticizing
dictionaryExamples: He has earned a reputation for making waves during political campaigns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we don't want to regret anything, it is time we started to make waves by s[c]rutinizing our history. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to be successful and make progress in your work
dictionaryExamples: He managed to make his way in the film industry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For each one of the famous sportsmen we re[cog]ni[z]e on television or in the newspapers, there are thousands of hopeful youngsters trying to make their way to the top. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to be replaced by someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They knocked down the old houses to make way for a new hotel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Local markets are broken down to make way for shopping malls, which sell items for the brand conscious population of today. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: to understand something that is difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: I'm trying to make sense of this document.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, it's during his journey that Stevens begins to make sense of his life, of all the years he spent as a butler, as the "perfect butler" who had to be loyal, silent and discreet. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to get a lot of public attention
dictionaryExamples: The movie made quite a splash in the US.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, it is no use splashing your money [around on] expensive gifts because this behavior shows that you are not happy but your purpose is to make a splash. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to move toward a place
dictionaryExamples: He got up and made for the exit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We might take a rest at the Frene Hotel and after having visited the Butterfly Farm, we will make for the Lakeside Inn. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to change something into something else
dictionaryExamples: They've made the spare room into an office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes people don't bother to read a book because it has been made into a film or a serie[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you ask someone what they make of someone or something, you want to know their opinion about that person or thing.
dictionaryExamples: What do you make of this letter?
I don't know what to make of him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first we did not know what to make of it and we were all dumbfounded; but later we realized that it was none other [than] the Icelandic lady out there on our lawn. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrasalVerb: make out sth/sb or make sth/sb out

sense.def: to be able to see, hear or understand something or someone but with difficulty
dictionaryExamples: We could just make out a building through the trees.
Could you make out what she was saying?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Somebody was standing outside, but she couldn't make out who [it] could be. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovene

blocks.phrasalVerb: make up sth or make sth up

sense.def: to say or write something that is not true
dictionaryExamples: I made up an excuse about having to look after the kids.
My dad was always really good at making up stories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Donald made up the best story. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to reduce the bad effect of something, or make something bad become something good
dictionaryExamples: No amount of money can make up for the death of a child.
This year's good harvest will make up for last year's bad one.

He bought me dinner to make up for being so late
                             the day before.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really want to make up for the broken vase, but I am not sure if you will like my choice. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the person or company that makes a product
dictionaryExamples: They're the biggest maker of fast-food products in the country.
The makers of the movie will want to see a decent return on their investment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: NISSAN is a famous Japanese car maker as you know. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: colored substances used on your face to improve or change your appearance
dictionaryExamples: She wears a lot of makeup.
I put on a little eye makeup.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like the bag because is very big.  I can put all my makeup in. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: belonging to or relating to the sex that cannot have babies
dictionaryExamples: a male colleague
a male giraffe
What percentage of the adult male population is unemployed?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was there when I heard a male voice calling me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a male person or animal
dictionaryExamples: In 1987, 27 percent of adult males smoked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a 30-year old Swedish male with a diploma in gardening. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: intended to harm or upset someone
dictionaryExamples: malicious gossip
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If malicious teasing is tolerated, the whole school will be affected in a negative way and nobody will feel safe and self-confident. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a large, usually covered, shopping area where cars are not allowed
dictionaryExamples: There are plans to build a new mall in the middle of town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go shopping too because there is a nice shopping mall in Punta del Este. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an animal that feeds its babies on milk from its body
dictionaryExamples: Dolphins and other sea mammals are being harmed by waste in the oceans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To admire some of the sea mammals, like the dol[ph]ins and the whales, the best possible spot would be a small, isolated Aegean isle. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an adult male human being
dictionaryExamples: a young/tall man
men and women
the man in the green jacket
the men's 400 meter champion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's a very good man. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin

sense.def: used to refer to both men and women
dictionaryExamples: Man is still more intelligent than the cleverest robot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Man must create the conditions so that [animals] can live, eat and procreate without strain. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to do something or deal with something successfully
dictionaryExamples: Did you manage to get any bread?
Anyway, we managed to get there on time.
I only just managed to finish on time.
Will you be able to manage without me?
I can't manage all this work on my own.
Don't worry about us - we'll manage!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I even phoned the bus company but I didn't manage to get the CDs back. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to be in control of an office, store, team, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She used to manage the bookstore on King Street.
Has Tom had any experience managing large projects?
He has managed the football team for the last five years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The English club is a student club which is managed by students age[d] from 13 to 20 who would like to improve their English. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to use or organize your time or money
dictionaryExamples: He's no good at managing his money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: London is the third most expensive city in the world after Tok[yo] and N.Y., so you will have to manage your money quite carefully. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: the control and organization of something
dictionaryExamples: The company has suffered from several years of bad management.
a management training program
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also know the basic rules of good management. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: someone in control of an office, shop, team, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a bank manager
the production manager
She's the manager of the local sports team.
May I speak to the manager?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will be the manager of the group. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a tropical fruit that has a green skin and is orange inside
dictionaryExamples: We had ice cream with slices of mango.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So anyway I'm here [at] the beach sunbathing, having a lovely time under the mango trees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Urdu

sense.def: all people, considered as a group
dictionaryExamples: the history of mankind
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since the beginning of human civilization, mankind has never ceased to be mesmerized by folklore and stories of princes and princesses. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the way something happens or something is done
dictionaryExamples: She stared at me in an accusing manner.
They dealt with the problem in a very efficient manner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't know if you [will] follow my advice, but [in] whichever manner you spend the money, I [hope] you are glad. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: polite ways of behaving with other people
dictionaryExamples: It's bad manners to eat with your mouth open.
It's considered good manners in some societies to leave a little food on your plate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Professional waiters are polite, tolerant and show good manners. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the way in which a person talks and behaves with other people
dictionaryExamples: an aggressive/friendly/rude manner
As soon as he realized that we weren't going to buy anything, his whole manner changed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stared at him in anger, and the poor man, afraid of my rude manner, went out [of] the cafe. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a very large expensive house
dictionaryExamples: The street is lined with enormous mansions where the rich and famous live.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you want to live in a grand mansion, an expensive flat or even a castle? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: involving physical work rather than mental work
dictionaryExamples: unskilled manual labor
750 manual workers will lose their jobs as a result of company cutbacks.
Computer-controlled robots are taking over manual jobs in many industries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, on the other hand, I sometimes think that th[is] tec[h]nolog[y] [is] the cause of the end of certain activities such as farming, or manual work. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: done or operated with the hands
dictionaryExamples: the manual sorting of letters
She tried to cure the pain in my knee by putting manual pressure on the joint.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has both manual and automatic functions so it has a lot of possibilities. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a book that tells you how to use something or do something
dictionaryExamples: You can download the manual for the computer if you need to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I need to read some manuals at work. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: to produce goods in large numbers, usually in a factory using machines
dictionaryExamples: He works for a company that manufactures car parts.
The report notes a rapid decline in manufactured goods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past I have worked in a company which manufactures computer games. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a company that produces goods in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: a shoe manufacturer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A]ir pollution could be reduced if car manufacturers and companies made effective filters [for] car exhausts and factory chimneys. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the business of producing goods in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: car/food manufacturing
the manufacturing of military equipment

the 
                      manufacturing industry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a translat[o]r for a manufacturing company. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a large number of
dictionaryExamples: We've known them for many years.
I don't have many clothes.
Were there many people at the party?
Not many people have heard of him.
Many people would disagree with your ideas.
I've met him so many times and I still can't remember his name!
There are too many people applying for too few jobs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [are] doing so many interesting things at college. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: used in questions to ask about the number of something
dictionaryExamples: How many people are coming tonight?
How many students are there in each class?
How many hours do you work?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How many friend[s] are coming? Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: used before a number or amount to show that the number or amount is large
dictionaryExamples: As many as 6,000 people may have been infected with the disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The quantities of goods by pipeline in 2002 was approximately 10 times as many as that in 1974, 21 and 2 million tonnes respectively. International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a picture that shows where countries, towns, roads, rivers, etc. are
dictionaryExamples: a map of the world
a map of Paris
a road map
I'm hopeless at map reading.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can get a map of the city in the train station. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a running race of slightly over 26 miles (42.195 kilometres)
dictionaryExamples: the London/New York marathon
She did/ran her first marathon in just under three hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How many hours of training per week are necessary if I want to run the marathon next year? First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the third month of the year, after February and before April
dictionaryExamples: the 26th of March/March 26th
My birthday is March eleventh.
He retired last March.
We're going to Australia next March.
We'll get together in March.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In March my country is very bea[u]tiful because spring is coming and [the] cold is over. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: an organized walk by a group to show that they disagree with something
dictionaryExamples: She's going on a  march on Saturday in protest over the closure of the hospital.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were protest marches and doctors, nurses, and the population forced the government to find a solution to the problem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to walk with other people in a public place as part of an organized event to show that you disagree with something
dictionaryExamples: Around twenty thousand people marched through the city today to protest against the proposed new law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was a time of rupture, a scream for freedom, for love, and for peace. Young boys and girls marched against war and at the same time killed themselves with drugs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to walk with regular steps, often with other people walking the same way
dictionaryExamples: The band marched through the downtown streets.
The soldiers marched 90 miles in three days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even when the Romans marched against Greece, the Greek people could[n't] unite against their new and powerful enemy and that's why they were conquered. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to walk somewhere fast and with purpose
dictionaryExamples: She marched into my office demanding to know why I hadn't written my report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She marched into the shop, got rid of the old lady and pestered the poor man until he agreed to give her the painting for £2982. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the difference between two amounts of time, money, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He was reelected by a wide margin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We chose the second one, and, incredible as it may seem, we managed to win by a rather comfortable margin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: empty space around the edges of a page of print or writing
dictionaryExamples: If I have any comments to make, I'll write them in the margin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That night, while he was going back to his native country, he anal[yz]ed the information written in the margins of the Lost Dairy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the amount by which a calculation can be wrong but still give a good result
dictionaryExamples: a margin of error of 5 percent
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It might be true that what is considered to be healthy or unhealthy changes over time, however, [as] science progresses the margin of error becomes smaller, and experts are then able to have a more accurate and precise say on all matters, including health. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the amount of profit that is made by a business after costs have been subtracted
dictionaryExamples: Higher fuel prices have reduced our margins.
Many farmers claim that the profit margin for growing trees remains slim.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first toys, he sold with a small profit margin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: small and not important
dictionaryExamples: a marginal difference/effect/improvement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Over-grazing had] the biggest impact in America, while deforestation caused only [a] marginal effect. International English Language Testing System; C2; Pashto

sense.def: a number or letter that is written on a piece of work, saying how good the work is
dictionaryExamples: What mark did you get in the biology exam?
She always gets good marks in English.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father gave it to me because I had good marks at school last year. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a small area on the surface of something which is damaged, dirty or different in some way
dictionaryExamples: There were dirty marks on her pants where she had wiped her hands.
His fingers had left marks on the table's polished surface.
She had a red mark on her arm where she'd burned herself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But one day, [when] I was about ten years old, my father had hurt me on the face and I had a blue mark on [my] cheek. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a symbol that is used for giving information
dictionaryExamples: I've put a mark on the map where I think we should go for a picnic.
What do those marks in the middle of the road mean?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you walk through the valley, always following the red marks on the path, you will run into many interesting views: from climbers climbing the walls of the valley to waterfalls coming from the top of it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: a sign or proof that something exists
dictionaryExamples: a mark of genius
There was a minute's silence everywhere as a mark of respect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To succe[ed] in a task that one has envision[ed] is a mark of success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to do something that makes you successful or makes people notice you
dictionaryExamples: He really made his mark on the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It teaches [you] that you don't have to be an Arnold Schwarzenegger to fight for your friends and really make your mark. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to check a piece of work or an exam, showing mistakes and giving a letter or number to say how good it is
dictionaryExamples: I was up half the night marking exam papers.
You'll be marked down  for poor spelling and punctuation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Computers even sell tickets [at] stations, mark exam papers, and help us to talk with people all over the world via [the] Internet. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to put a line, symbol, letter, etc., on something as a label or to show something
dictionaryExamples: I've marked my street on the map for you.
X marks the spot where the treasure is buried.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the map we have marked a black dot on the place where you will find the hotel. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to put a spot, color, ink, dirt, etc., on a small area of something
dictionaryExamples: Sale items are marked with red on the tags.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: See all paragraphs marked in green. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to represent or show a characteristic of a person or thing or feeling
dictionaryExamples: The signing of the treaty marked a major milestone on the road to European union.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These books, most of which are very scientific, marked the beginning of a new era of enlight[en]ment and technology. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a place where people go to buy or sell things, often outside
dictionaryExamples: a fish/flower market
Fruit and vegetables are much cheaper from/at the market.
a craft market
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Juan, My new house is [in] Balmoral Street, near the market. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: all the people who want to buy a particular product, or the area where they live
dictionaryExamples:
Is there a market for 
                          second-hand jewelry?
Spain is our largest market.
They've increased their share of the market by 10% over the past year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had been researching the market for a year. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the number of people in a place who are available and willing to work
dictionaryExamples: The strong economy will create growth in the labor market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The labor market in Russia is greatly influenced by the political situation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: the business of  buying and selling a particular product or service
dictionaryExamples: the insurance/housing market
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually the enumeration of problems includes facts such as the difficulties that are caused in countries which run state-administered pension schemes, distortions in the age structure of developed countries, problems [with] the housing market, and so on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: work that involves encouraging people to buy a product or service
dictionaryExamples: a career in marketing/sales and marketing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am studying marketing now so I will be available at the end of April. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: the legal relationship of a man and a woman being a husband and a wife, or the ceremony where people become a husband and a wife
dictionaryExamples: They had a long and happy marriage.
She went to live abroad after the break-up of her marriage.
She has two daughters by her first marriage.
a marriage certificate
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the marriage they go to a restaurant and eat something. Preliminary English Test; B1; Armenian

sense.def: to begin a legal relationship with someone as their husband or wife
dictionaryExamples: Will you marry me?
They don't have any plans to marry at present.
He never married.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before we left the airport, John w[h]ispered in my ear "I'm going to marry her". Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: one of the traditional Japanese or Chinese skills of fighting, done as sports in many countries, for example karate or kung fu
dictionaryExamples: Kuk Sool Won is a martial art from Korea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've been doing different martial arts since I moved to Balingen in 1990. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: extremely good
dictionaryExamples: I thought it was a marvelous movie.
It took me ages to get it right, but it was a marvelous feeling when I did.
It's marvelous how everyone's tried to help.
We've achieved some marvelous results with this new drug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a beautiful and marvelous day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: having qualities that are typical of men
dictionaryExamples: a masculine appearance/voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Mexico, husbands traditionally avoid doing housework. They feel that it is a woman's exclusive task.  If they wash the dishes they are not masculine any more. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a covering for the face which protects, hides or decorates the person wearing it
dictionaryExamples: a gas mask
a surgical mask
The bank robbers wore masks throughout the raid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly five men with masks jump[ed] from nowhere into the bank and started to threat[en] us with their guns. First Certificate in English; B2; Vietnamese

sense.def: the killing of a lot of people
dictionaryExamples: He ordered the massacre of over 2,000 women and children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was mostly used for military purposes, thus provoking huge disasters and massacres. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: very large in size, amount or number
dictionaryExamples: They've got a massive house.
She died after taking a massive overdose of drugs.
If the drought continues, deaths will occur on a massive scale.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sea pollution can be reduced if [people] take more care [with] oil tankers, to reduce massive oil spills. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a man who is in charge of a servant or a dog
dictionaryExamples: With careful training, a dog will obey its master completely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We must [remember] that we are masters of the car not the servants of the car. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a higher university title of achievement
dictionaryExamples: to study for a Master's degree
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is [the] second year since I got my master's. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a person who does something with a lot of skill
dictionaryExamples: This painting is clearly the work of a master.
a master chef/craftsman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Beckman is a master in telling her stories through the eyes of a child. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a painting, book, or movie that is generally considered to be of excellent quality
dictionaryExamples: "Mona Lisa" is widely regarded as Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My choice was Chinua Achebe's masterpiece "Things Fall Apart." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of thick material that you put on the floor, often in order to protect it
dictionaryExamples: There's a mat by the door for you to wipe your feet on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, many Japanese style hotels and restaurants now have square holes in tatami (straw mat) rooms so that foreign visitors can comfortably stretch their legs under the low table without having to be seated on folded legs like Zen monks! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a sports competition in which two people or teams compete against each other
dictionaryExamples: a tennis match
She won/lost the match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like [to] play a tennis match [at] your house, and go out tonight too. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a thin, wooden stick which produces a flame when you rub one end of it against a rough surface
dictionaryExamples: a box of matches
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [lit] a match and I went to the kitchen to get a candle, but there weren't any. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something which is similar to or combines well with something else
dictionaryExamples: The curtains look great - they're a perfect match for the sofa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Marine science would be a perfect match for people [interested in] natural sciences. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to not be as good as someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Gibson ran well but was no match for the young Italian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This exhibition was [e]specially striking because almost all the prints were from the very first series [of] vintage prints, in addition [to]  being rare [and] also highly valued by collectors, even though their prices are no match for the Picasso. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to light a match in order to produce fire
dictionaryExamples: I struck a match and lit the candle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their instant reaction was to park the car, put their raincoats on, get out and strike a few useless matches: they were their last light resour[c]e apart from the lightning in the sky and the weak [head]lights. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If two things match, they are the same color or type.
dictionaryExamples: I can't find anything to match my green shirt.
Your socks don't match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They match a T-shirt that I bought last week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to choose someone or something that is suitable for a particular person, activity or purpose
dictionaryExamples: In the first exercise you have to match each capital city to its country.

sense.def: to be as good as someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: It would be difficult to match the service this airline gives to its customers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In all these ways that your establishment failed to match the claims made for it in your publicity, we feel entitled to a full refund and I therefore urge you to improve the facilities of your museum or withdraw the advertisement to avoid further complaints. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: cloth for making clothes, curtains, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Her dress was made of a soft, silky material.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like buying designer clothes because they're made of  good material. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: documents, recorded information, etc. that are used for a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: publicity material
She writes all her own teaching materials.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the lesson we use a lot of useful and helpful material: tapes, video, and lots of different books. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a physical substance that has a particular quality or is used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: building materials, such as stone
Crude oil is used as the raw  material for making plastics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They wear plastic in their hair and clothes [that] are made from recycled materials. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: the facts or ideas in a piece of writing
dictionaryExamples: I'm collecting material for an article that I'm writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are mainly interested in gathering material and data. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Singhalese

sense.def: the belief that having money and possessions is the most important thing in life
dictionaryExamples: She was saddened by the materialism of our society.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We consume, not for the benefit of our social status, but to satisfy our need for material goods. This phenomenon, called materialism, characterizes our society. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a person who thinks that having money and possessions is the most important thing in life
dictionaryExamples: We hope our children will not be materialists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, I would say that I am not a materialist but some things have a great value [in] my eyes and pictures are one of those things. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: believing that having money and possessions is the most important thing in life
dictionaryExamples: We live in a materialist society.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To be able to understand their labor we must separate ourselves from the materialist world we are living in. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: believing that having money and possessions is the most important thing in life
dictionaryExamples: a materialistic society
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When parents put instead of their presence, presents, aren't we replacing love with materialism, where the children in turn become materialistic rather than loving? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the study of numbers, shapes and space using reason and usually a special system of symbols and rules for organizing them
dictionaryExamples: Math is my favorite subject!
a math teacher
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Robert, I think I left my math book in your house last night. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: relating to mathematics
dictionaryExamples: a mathematical formula
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, he studied the human body and invented mathematical formulas to describe his findings. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: Mature people behave like adults in a way that shows they are well developed emotionally.
dictionaryExamples: She seems very mature for thirteen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time I thought of it before entering college, I expected to find intelligent, kind, [and] mature people, [though] of course, some rude, mean and stupid people as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to increase something as much as you can
dictionaryExamples: to maximize profits
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can assure you that I would make every possible effort to maximize the outcome of this project. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: The maximum amount of something is the largest amount that is allowed or possible.
dictionaryExamples: maximum speed/effort/temperature
The bomb was designed to cause the maximum amount of damage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [F]rom now on, my house will have maximum security (tanks, soldiers, bombs) so no one can kidnap my family again. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the largest amount allowed or possible
dictionaryExamples: The temperature will reach a maximum of 60°F today.
The school has a maximum of 30 students per class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I watch 1 hour of television a day, maximum. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to talk about what will possibly happen
dictionaryExamples: We may go to France later this year.
I may see you tomorrow - it depends on when we leave.
The cause of the accident may never be discovered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we may go sightseeing. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used to talk about what is possibly true
dictionaryExamples: There may be other problems that we don't know about.
I think I may be getting a cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know it may be difficult, because [it] is not that easy to find [a] house, but please can you do your best and find something for us very soon. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Slovak

sense.def: used to ask or give permission
dictionaryExamples: May I be excused, please?
"May I help myself to some more food?" "Yes, of course."
You may begin.
Hi, my name's Tiffany. How may I help you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Friends, May I sug[g]est [that] you spend your time in the city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to talk about things that possibly happened in the past or might possibly have happened by a certain time in the future
dictionaryExamples: The explosion may have been caused by a faulty electrical connection.
That may not have been Mike's brother you met - I think his cousin is staying with him at the moment.
Helen may have already left by the time you arrive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, your report is full of mistakes, so it seem[s] to me that you may not have been well informed. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to suggest doing something when there is no reason you should not do it or there is no  better thing to do
dictionaryExamples: We may as well start the meeting - the others will be here soon.
If the stores are closed, we may as well go home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can reduce costs, taking adv[a]ntage of their special offer. We may as well cut o[u]r costs, taking group discounts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the fifth month of the year, after April and before June
dictionaryExamples: the 30th of May/May 30(th)
My mother's birthday is in May.
They came over last May.
We'll see her next May.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] water temp[e]rature [is] 18°C to 26°C all summer (May to end of Sept). Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: possibly
dictionaryExamples: Maybe we're too early.
Maybe they'll come tomorrow.
Maybe you were right after all.
It could take a month, or maybe more, to complete.
"Are you coming to Kelly's party?" "Maybe."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe I forgot it [in] your room. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: used to politely suggest something
dictionaryExamples: Maybe Ted would like to go.
Maybe we should start again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe we could visit that park you told me about or play at your house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the person who is elected to govern a city or town
dictionaryExamples: the mayor of Boston
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I am sure you know, my name is Jane Brown, and I am the mayor's secretary. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used after a verb or preposition to refer to the person who is speaking or writing
dictionaryExamples: Is there one for me?
She gave me some money.
Could you pass me that book?
It wasn't me who offered to go, it was Charlotte.
Lydia is three years younger than me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is difficult for me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: accept that what I say is true, because I know or have experienced it
dictionaryExamples: You could be doing a much less interesting job, take it from me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you pro[b]ably already know, Greeks love sport[s] so, take it from me, you won't have difficulty in finding sports facilities of any kind, wherever you decide to go. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an occasion when food is eaten, or the food which is eaten on such an occasion
dictionaryExamples: make/prepare/cook a meal
a three-course meal
They had to leave before the meal was served.
The fee for the program includes three meals a day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope we have a great meal and a lot of fun. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to have a particular meaning
dictionaryExamples: What does "gather" mean?
The red light means stop.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because, in my opinion, blue means freedom. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: something that you say in order to correct yourself
dictionaryExamples: We went there in May - I mean June.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have time - I mean if you are free. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: to intend to express a fact or opinion
dictionaryExamples: I didn't mean that as a criticism.
That's what I meant when I said he's been acting oddly.
What exactly do you mean by "old-fashioned"?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I know what you mean when you say this island is wonderful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: to have an important emotional effect on someone
dictionaryExamples: It wasn't a valuable picture but it meant a lot to me.
Possessions mean nothing to him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's my grandfather's birthday and he means a lot to me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to intend
dictionaryExamples: I think she meant 8 o’clock, although she said 7 o’clock.
Sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I didn't mean to scare you. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

blocks.phrase: have been meaning to do sth

sense.def: to have been wanting and planning to do something
dictionaryExamples: I've been meaning to call you for weeks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Claude, I have been meaning to write for ages! Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to have or need a particular result
dictionaryExamples: Lower costs mean lower prices.
These changes will mean better health care for everyone.
Advances in electronics mean that the technology is already available.
If we want to catch the 7:30 train, that will mean leaving the house at 6:00.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This doesn't mean that you won't be able to enjoy the countryside, in fact most of these cities are surrounded by nature, so you'll have wonderful views. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to be made or created for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: These toys are really meant for babies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cities are meant for human activities and not for heavy traffic. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to intend to be helpful or kind but cause problems instead
dictionaryExamples: He means well, but he keeps trying to help with things he doesn't really understand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although these fans might mean well, in many cases they do not appear to reali[z]e that their "heroes" perhaps would like to be left alone. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: unkind or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: Stop being so mean to me!
She just said it to be mean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand people, when driving a car, can be very mean and wicked, and they sure don't have a bit of respect for the next man. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: In math, a mean number is the average number you get by adding a group of numbers together and then dividing the result by how many numbers are in the group
dictionaryExamples: The mean temperature this  month was warmer than usual for January.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Better living conditions and significant advances in medicine have greatly contributed to an increase in the mean age of death and a decrease in deaths at birth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you want to emphasize that an act or achievement is very difficult
dictionaryExamples: Learning to ski at 60 is no mean feat!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was an interesting discussion about whether it was harder or easier for them to enter the world of cinema, given their famous names. Both said that it was no mean feat because people were more demanding as [to] their abilities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: The meaning of words, signs, or actions is what they express or represent.
dictionaryExamples: The word "squash" has several meanings.
The meaning of his gesture was clear.
His novels often have a hidden meaning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I didn't understand the meaning of a word, she told me and gave me a dictionary to look up the words. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: purpose or emotional importance
dictionaryExamples: She felt that her life had no meaning.
The birth of her first grandchild gave new meaning to her life.
the meaning of life
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can give meaning [to] our lives, with everyday little things. First Certificate in English; B2; Albanian

sense.def: useful, serious, or important
dictionaryExamples: a meaningful discussion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I think this camp c[ould] be very meaningful for children, to be close to nature and to understand Japan. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: having a clear meaning which people can understand
dictionaryExamples: The information needs to be presented in a meaningful way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The music is really amazing and the lyrics are so meaningful. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a method or way of doing something
dictionaryExamples: They had no means of communication.
We need to find some other means of transportation.
The family had no means of support.
She tried to explain by means of sign language.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think if the government improves the public means of transportation, more and more people will use them. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

blocks.phrase: by no means; not by any means

sense.def: not in any way
dictionaryExamples: I'm not an expert by any means.
It is by no means clear what the mayor can do to end the strike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For one thing, the fight against air pollution is by no means an easy mission. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: using, or with this method
dictionaryExamples: Students are selected for scholarships by means of an open, national competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another plus of the Voiceover CD is [the] availability  of teachers, who can be easily reached by means of a telephone, but this kind of service is expensive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: something that you say when you are agreeing to let someone do something
dictionaryExamples: I have a copy of the report on my desk. By all means have a look at it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The kitchen utensils stay next to the sink. You can make use of them by all means. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: something that you do because it will help you to achieve something else
dictionaryExamples: I didn't particularly like the job - it was just a means to an end.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Major international sports competitions can either be understood as a means to an end or an end in their own right. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: money
dictionaryExamples: We don't have the means to buy the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the people don't have the means to travel, too. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in the time between two things happening, or while something else is happening
dictionaryExamples: Carl's starting college in September. Meanwhile, he's traveling around Europe.
The mother is ill. The child, meanwhile, is living with his grandparents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Meanwhile, if you agree, I can do some English exercises to cover the class that I'm going to miss. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to discover the exact size or amount of something, or to be of a particular size
dictionaryExamples: "Will the table fit in here?" "I don't know - let's measure it."
He measured the flour into the bowl.
This machine measures your heart rate.
The area, measuring 5 miles by 3 miles, has been purchased by the army.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I measured how long they played [for], because I was one of the group's fans. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to be a certain size
dictionaryExamples: a whale measuring around 60 feet in length.
The sofa measures 3 feet by 7 feet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But there is still one major problem: Bielefeld is the main big city in a region measuring about 50 km in diameter. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to judge the quality, effect, importance, or value of something
dictionaryExamples: We will soon be able to measure the results of these policies.
They measured the performance of three different engines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The paramet[er]s for measuring success would be vastly different depending on which walk of life is being described, so in the following, the definition of success has been narrowed down to a specific domain: the international computer industry. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a way of achieving something or dealing with a situation
dictionaryExamples: These measures were designed to improve car safety.
We must take preventative measures to stop the spread of the disease.
This arrangement is only a temporary measure.
security measures
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are a lot of measures that we have taken in [the] last three years. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: a way of judging something
dictionaryExamples: Ticket sales are not necessarily a measure of the show's popularity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, these two experiences from my childhood taught me a lot of real truth about life and since that time they have been serving me as a measure of my affection or attachment, sorrow or disappointment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: amount or degree
dictionaryExamples: Heavy drapes give the room some measure of warmth on cold nights.
There was a large measure of luck in his quick promotion to company vice president.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The important [thing] is to have the right measure of material richness [so as] not to le[t] the negative aspects of it [change us] and to help us to achieve spiritual richness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the exact size, shape, degree or strength of something which you discover by measuring it
dictionaryExamples: The measurements of both rooms were identical.
They've taken measurements of air quality around the bus station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We sat day and night to document the results of our measurements of polluted ground all over Sweden. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the process of measuring something, or a way of measuring something
dictionaryExamples: The test is based on the measurement of blood sugar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The measurement of a child by academic achievement at school is in my opinion very important as the future of a society or even more of a country depends on the high [shared] knowledge of the people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: muscles and other soft parts of animals, used as food
dictionaryExamples: I don't eat meat.
raw meat
red/white meat
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like meat and fish. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: someone whose job is repairing the engines of vehicles and other machines
dictionaryExamples: a car/garage/motor mechanic
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I w[o]rked as [a] mechanic in my country. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: relating to or operated by machines
dictionaryExamples: a mechanical device
a mechanical engineer
The plane appears to have crashed because of a mechanical problem.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, the car had a mechanical defect and I needed to stay almost five hours in an old and dirty garage, waiting [for] the car to be fixed. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you do something in a mechanical way, you do it without thinking about it.
dictionaryExamples: a mechanical performance
The men worked in a slow, mechanical way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We end up doing our things in such a mechanical way that the actual spirit of doing dies in us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a part of a piece of equipment that does a particular job
dictionaryExamples: The clock's winding mechanism was broken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most chairs' adjusting mechanism[s] failed to work properly and they are not comfortable to sit on. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a system for achieving something, or the way that a system works
