dictionaryExamples: We need a mechanism for resolving this sort of dispute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The definition of market here not only means a traditional marketplace for goods exchange and barter, but it extends further to a supply-sell mechanism which domina[te]s the normal liv[es] of all [in]habitants. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a metal disk given as a prize in a competition or given to someone who has been very brave
dictionaryExamples: an Olympic medal
She won three gold medals.
He was awarded a medal for bravery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [T]hey can also take part in sport[s] competitions and win a medal. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: relating to medicine and different ways of curing illness
dictionaryExamples: medical advice
medical treatment
a medical student
a medical team
She has a medical condition that makes it hard for her to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the help of medical technology doctors can cure more and more patients [and] do many kinds of operations. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in a way that is connected to medicine or to someone's health
dictionaryExamples: A stay in the hospital was not medically necessary, so the doctor said he could go home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This does seem wise, as there is no "medically proven" diet or nutrition program that might help everyone to achieve [a] state of health that they would be completely happy about. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: medicine that is used to treat an illness
dictionaryExamples: He's on medication to control his depression.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had to put up with unbelievably painful treatments and was forced to take medication which prevented him from continuing his research. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a substance used to cure an illness or injury
dictionaryExamples: cough medicine
Take two spoonfuls of medicine at mealtimes.
The government appealed for food and medicines after the earthquake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Felix, Thank you inviting me last night. I think I have left my asthma medicine at your house. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: treatment for illness or injury, or the study of this
dictionaryExamples: Western/Chinese medicine
a career in medicine
She is a doctor, but is unable to practice medicine  in her own country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is twenty three years old and she's studying medicine, here in Colombia. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to the period in Europe between about AD 500 and AD 1500
dictionaryExamples: a medieval building/painting/town
a medieval manuscript
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On our way around the lake we would have [the opportunity]  of visiting a huge medieval castle which is said to be haunted. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not good in quality
dictionaryExamples: The acting was mediocre.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Hungary, the sports facilities provided are quite mediocre. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: the state of being mediocre
dictionaryExamples: I was shocked by the mediocrity of these students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a model of mediocrity and shallowness, and in this sense, she epitomi[z]e[s] what authorities expect people to be: just ghosts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: in the middle of a group of different amounts or sizes
dictionaryExamples: a girl of medium height
She bought a medium-sized car.
All shirts come in small, medium, and large.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What size are you? Are you small or medium? Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a way of communicating or expressing something
dictionaryExamples: the medium of television/radio
the print medium
The Internet has become yet another medium for marketing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As with any other medium of communication or entertainment, nothing is totally good or bad provided it is done in moderation. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: to see and speak to someone for the first time
dictionaryExamples: They met at work.
I met her in Hawaii.
Have you met my sister?
Come and meet  my friend Laura.
"This is Helen." "Pleased to meet you."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At college you can meet new people. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to come to the same place as someone else by arrangement or by chance
dictionaryExamples: We met for coffee last Sunday.
We agreed to meet on Tuesday to discuss the project.
I met my old English teacher while hiking in the Alps.
We met our old neighbors in town last Saturday.
Each student meets with an adviser at the start of the school year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I meet with my friends there. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a polite way of greeting someone when you meet them for the first time
dictionaryExamples: I'm very pleased to meet you at last!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will be pleased to meet you. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to wait at a place for someone or something to arrive
dictionaryExamples: Will you meet me at the airport ?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please meet me [at] London Heathrow at 12:00 am.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: If a group of people meet, they come to a place in order to do something.
dictionaryExamples: The children's club meets every Thursday afternoon.
The shareholders meet once a year to discuss profits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The members meet at the club every weekend. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be a big enough amount or of a good enough quality for something
dictionaryExamples: We couldn't find a house that met our needs.
This old building will never meet the new fire regulations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even though its construction would mean mayhem and chaos for the length of the project, and the fact that it would hold less cars than the alternative, its exclusive location in the middle of the commercial district meets the needs of the growing number of business people working in town. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to have just enough money to pay for the things that you need
dictionaryExamples: I had to get a second job just to make ends meet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most students support themselves and barely make ends meet every month. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to be able to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: He met every goal he set for himself.
I've got a deadline to meet.
Do you think we will be able to meet our target?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was trying hard to meet our requirements and it really took a lot out of her. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: an event where people come together for a reason, usually to discuss something
dictionaryExamples: We're having a meeting on Thursday to discuss the problem.
I'm afraid she's in a meeting - I'll ask her to call you back later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm free to come to a meeting about this tomorrow at six o'clock p.m. See you [then]! Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to arrange for a meeting to happen
dictionaryExamples: The chairman has called an emergency meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We hope you w[ill] call a meeting to discuss this matter in detail. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: the main tune in a piece of music that is often played or sung more than once
dictionaryExamples: He played a beautiful melody.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From his harp, violin, flute, trumpet and many more instruments sprang such a wonderful, enchanting melody that the whole city flourished, thrilled and cheered under its influence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a large, round, sweet fruit with a thick, green or yellow skin and a lot of seeds
dictionaryExamples: a slice of melon
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to buy melons, tomatoes, apples and pears. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: If something melts, it changes from a solid into a liquid because of heat and if you melt something, you heat it until it becomes liquid.
dictionaryExamples: The snow usually melts by mid March.
Melt the chocolate slowly so that it doesn't burn.
melted cheese
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Walking out of the station he saw her!  Tall, blond and with eyes that could melt ice. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a person who belongs to a group or an organization
dictionaryExamples: family/staff members
a member of the older generation
He was a member of the university rowing team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The living room] provides a huge place for all of my family members. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the state of being a member of a group or organization
dictionaryExamples: We applied for membership in the country club.
a membership card/fee
Some fitness clubs sell lifetime memberships.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First, the president welcomed me and gave me my membership card. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: all the members of a group or organization
dictionaryExamples: We asked the membership to vote on the issue.
Membership is now over three million and rising.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, we found that our club's membership is actually falling. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a written message sent from one member of an organization to another
dictionaryExamples: Did you see the memo about expenses?
He put his conclusions in a memo to the committee secretary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will send Mr. Pusinshg's e-mail ad[d]ress in a memo if you require it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: If an occasion is memorable, you will remember it for a long time because it is so good.
dictionaryExamples: a memorable performance
a memorable evening
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a memorable birthday party because they bought me a bass guitar that I couldn't buy because of its high price. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: an object, often made of stone, that is built to help people remember an important person or event
dictionaryExamples: the Lincoln Memorial
The statue was erected as a memorial to those who died in the war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every year almost all [the] inhabitants of our suburb gather at the memorial and celebrate this anniversary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the amount of information that can be stored on a computer or other electronic device
dictionaryExamples: You need 128 megabytes of memory to run this software.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't forget it has 4GB [of] memory. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: your ability to remember
dictionaryExamples: You have a good memory.
She has an excellent memory for names.
He had a photographic memory.
memory loss
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's about a girl that lives in London and she lost her memory so everybody has to tell her everything about the past. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something that you remember from the past
dictionaryExamples: I have very fond memories of that period of my life.
I have vivid memories of that evening.
That tune really brings back memories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have so many good memories. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the part of your mind that stores what you remember
dictionaryExamples: He recited the poem from memory.

sense.def: If you do something in memory of a dead person, you do it to show your respect or love for them.
dictionaryExamples: They built a statue in memory of those who died in the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You see, every year our family performs a certain gathering in memory of my brother who was killed in a plane crash in 1991 known as the C130 disaster. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an occasion when you remember some of the good things you did in the past
dictionaryExamples: We were just taking a walk down memory lane and recalling our youth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to return there, without the kids, even without my husband, to have a long stroll down memory lane. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: relating to the mind, or involving the process of thinking
dictionaryExamples: mental health/illness
She had a mental picture  of how the house would look when they finished decorating it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His theories have changed our attitude towards mental illness (and mental health) completely. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a person's opinions or way of thinking
dictionaryExamples: They buy everything on credit – they have this play now, pay later mentality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is why the changing mentality of men plays an important role. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: connected with or related to the mind
dictionaryExamples: mentally ill
It's going to be a tough competition but I'm mentally prepared for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most people believe that team sport[s] help children to become healthier, both mentally and physically, but there are those who have objections to this statement. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to briefly speak or write about something or someone
dictionaryExamples: She didn't mention her daughter.
I'll mention your ideas to Jacinta.
He casually mentioned that he was leaving his job.
Did she happen to mention whether she would be coming?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You mentioned you are coming to visit my country. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: used to emphasize the importance of something that you are adding to a list
dictionaryExamples: The resort has great hotels and restaurants, not to mention some of the best skiing in the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is crowded everywhere, the shop assist[a]nts are stressed, you get to wait for hours to pay for your goods, not to mention the time you must wait to get them wrapped. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a brief remark
dictionaryExamples: When I ordered the catalog, there was no mention of any payment.
The report made no mention of the problem.
The story didn't even get a mention in the newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the advertisement there's no mention about getting any money back but I think it was such a disappointing evening that you should give it back to me. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a list of food and drinks that you can order in a restaurant
dictionaryExamples: a lunch/dinner menu
The waiter brought the menu and the wine list.
I ordered the most expensive thing on the menu.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's for celebrations bec[a]use [it] is [a] very nice menu. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a list that appears on a computer screen of the choices available in a computer program
dictionaryExamples: a pop-up menu
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it because it has a big screen and easy menu. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: kind and forgiving
dictionaryExamples: Judges are sometimes more merciful than a jury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He would have seven children, all of them would be merciful and good rulers of rich countries. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: cruel, or showing no kindness
dictionaryExamples: a merciless attack
She was merciless in her criticism of his work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sheila, being at least aware how deeply her merciless behavior changed Eve's life, was the only person in the family who [was] taught [a] lesson. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: kindness that makes you forgive someone, usually someone that you have authority over
dictionaryExamples: The judge showed no mercy.
The prisoners begged/pleaded for mercy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The doctor showed no mercy and neither would Douglas. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrase: be at the mercy of sb/sth

sense.def: to not be able to protect yourself from something or someone that you cannot control
dictionaryExamples: Farmers are often at the mercy of the weather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't believe I'd been careless enough to let them be at the mercy of Joanna's careless, boisterous friends, and I felt very lonely now, looking for them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: used to emphasize that something is not large or important
dictionaryExamples: It cost a mere twenty dollars.

The mere thought of 
                          eating octopus makes me feel sick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fight was just a mere coincidence. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: used to emphasize that you mean exactly what you are saying and nothing more
dictionaryExamples: I wasn't complaining, I merely said that I was tired.
I didn't say that you had to go - I merely suggested that you might like to go.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course this is merely a suggestion, and if you have got anything else in mind please don't hesitate to let me know. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used to say something is or does only this or is not large or important when compared to something else
dictionaryExamples: The medicine doesn't make you better, it merely stops the pain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For a reasonably high entrance fee a visitor can a[c]quire the help of a skilled instructor or merely enjoy skating. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If two or more things merge, they combine or join, and if you merge two or more things, you combine or join them.
dictionaryExamples: The two companies merged.
They're planning to merge the banks.
The city's smaller libraries will be merged into a large, central one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What will happen if the biggest companies go on merging and reducing the number of their employees? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when two or more companies or organizations join together
dictionaryExamples: The two companies announced their merger yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, in Korea where conglomerates as well as small companies [have] announce[d] their bankrup[t]cy or are in the state of liquidation or merger, millions of people are on the verge of being laid off and unemployed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: good qualities that deserve praise
dictionaryExamples: His ideas have merit.
We debated the merits of using video in the classroom.

Every application has to be judged on its own 
                         merits (=judged by considering the qualities of each).
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, everything has its own merits. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to be important enough to receive attention or punishment
dictionaryExamples: Her crimes were serious enough to merit a prison sentence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One thing which merits serious consideration is the consequences of this invasion in famous private li[ves]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: Something or someone that is a mess or is in a mess, looks dirty and disorganized and is not neat.
dictionaryExamples: My hair's such a mess!
The house is in a mess.
He makes a terrible mess when he's cooking.
Go and clean up that mess in the kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now my room is a mess because I have so much stuff. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a situation that is full of problems
dictionaryExamples: She said that her life was a mess.
The company's finances are in a mess.
If he hadn't lied, he wouldn't be in this mess now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How on earth did I get into this mess? First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to waste time playing and doing things with no particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: I was just messing around on the computer.
Stop messing around and do your homework!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To add more, on Thursday there were so [many] children messing around that we couldn't supervise them, as we were only two people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to interfere with or change something that doesn't need to be changed or that you don't want changed
dictionaryExamples: Has someone been messing around with the settings on my  computer again?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She can't help messing around with your house-keeping and your cooking. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: mess up sth or mess sth up

sense.def: to spoil something, or to do something badly
dictionaryExamples: Don't try to cook lunch without me - you'll only mess it up.
I feel I've messed up my chances of getting the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I ignored the price and just pa[i]d because I didn't want to mess up the evening. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a piece of writing or spoken information that one person gives to another
dictionaryExamples: Did you get my message?
I've left her several messages, but she hasn't returned my call.
Could you give Jen a message from me, please?
I got your message that you were going to be late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for your message. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: the most important idea in a book, movie or play
dictionaryExamples: The book conveys a complex message.
The movie's message is that ultimately, rich and poor are alike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has a clear message: if you desire something, you can [achieve] whatever you want, but [only] with enormous effort and the danger of losing everything you posses[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a place on a website where you can leave messages for other people to read
dictionaryExamples: There's a lot of discussion on the message boards about this issue.

sense.def: disorganized or dirty and not neat
dictionaryExamples: a messy kitchen
messy hair
His bedroom's always messy.
My kids are both really messy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's completely messy now, looks like a war in my bedroom, because my bed has broken and I need to buy a new bed quickly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a usually hard, shiny material such as iron, gold, or silver which heat and electricity can travel through
dictionaryExamples: Metal, paper and glass can be recycled.
Silver, gold and platinum are precious metals.
Metals are used for making machinery and tools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was made of metal and wood. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a way of describing something by comparing it with something else which has some of the same qualities
dictionaryExamples: She used a computer metaphor to explain how the human brain works.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I shall use a metaphor to help me express my idea. An individual can be compared to a ship roaming the oceans. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a unit for measuring length, equal to 100 centimeters
dictionaryExamples: Our bedroom is five meters wide.
a 15-meter yacht
She won the 100 meters  at the Olympics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Walk 100 meters and the firs[t] street left is my street. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a way of doing something, often one that involves a system or plan
dictionaryExamples: What's the best method of/for solving this problem?
Traveling by train is still one of the safest methods of transportation.
traditional teaching methods
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think her teaching method is modern, up to date, and I hope I'll finally improve my English. Preliminary English Test; B1; Indonesian

sense.def: very careful, and giving great attention to detail
dictionaryExamples: This book is the result of meticulous research.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, taking photos entails paying attention to detail and although I am not a talent, I am a meticulous person. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of equipment that you speak into to make your voice louder, or to record your voice or other sounds
dictionaryExamples: The interviewer asked her to speak into/use the microphone.
My laptop has a built-in microphone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we had to plug [in] all [the] electric instruments, speakers, lights and microphones. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in the middle of your life before you are old
dictionaryExamples: a middle-aged couple/man/woman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our teacher is a middle-aged lady with a kind smile and British accent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the social group consisting of people who are neither very rich nor very poor
dictionaryExamples: These tax increases will affect the middle class badly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They also show the efforts parents make to keep the family happy, especially when the middle class in Argentina started to struggle after the economic crisis in 2001. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: belonging to or relating to the working class
dictionaryExamples: Working-class families can't afford these prices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And young people from working-class families in the suburbs of Paris will make a point of having the latest fashion shoes or trousers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: 12 o'clock at night
dictionaryExamples: We didn't get home till midnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We stayed until midnight dancing and singing. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: to work late into the night
dictionaryExamples: I had to burn the midnight oil to get the essay finished.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My examinations were nearing and I was always burning the midnight oil. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: used to talk about what will possibly happen
dictionaryExamples: We might finish the project by Thursday.
She might not come.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We shou[l]d wear t-shirts to paint the wall because the paint might make our t-shirts dirty. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used to talk about what is possibly true
dictionaryExamples: I think Isabel might be pregnant.
Don't go any closer - it might be dangerous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first, I thought it might be a mistake. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to talk about things that possibly happened in the past or could possibly have happened by some time in the future
dictionaryExamples: It might have been Alex who called.
The rain might have stopped by lunchtime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, you might have been thinking you have to go to a sports club or somewhere and exer[c]ise very hard to keep fit. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: used to suggest doing something when there is no reason you should not do it or there is no better thing to do
dictionaryExamples: We might as well walk there.
I think everyone is here now, so we might as well start the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But we have to have a starting point, and since we are not sure how to do it, I believe we might as well start by thinking that "I am important, therefore I'm going to give time to myself, set up priorities and put aside what will harm me." First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: very powerful or successful
dictionaryExamples: In their next game they're playing the mighty Redskins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Teotihuacan was the place that saw the rise and fall of the mighty "Nahvatlaca Tribe." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when people go to another place to live or find work, or when an animal or bird moves to another place, usually when the season changes
dictionaryExamples: There was a mass migration of poor farmers into the cities.
The butterflies come to Mexico during their annual migration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is also migration, people from little villages in the interior migrate to the coast. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: describes weather that is not very cold or not as cold as usual
dictionaryExamples: We've had a mild winter this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know, my country has got mild weather. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: describes food or a food flavor that is not very strong
dictionaryExamples: a mild chili sauce
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Korean food is quite hot and usually served with rice, but Thai food is mild and sometimes a little bit sour. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: slight or gentle, not violent, severe or extreme
dictionaryExamples: She can't accept even mild criticism of her work.
He has suffered a mild heart attack - nothing too serious.
a mild case of the flu
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Music has either a strong or a mild impact (depending [on] the person) on our lives. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a unit for measuring distance, equal to 1609 meters or 1760 yards
dictionaryExamples: a ten-mile drive
The nearest town is ten miles away.
The latest high-speed trains can travel at 140 miles an/per hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took her for [the] day to Krako[w], which is only 10 miles from where I live. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: a very long distance
dictionaryExamples: We drove for miles along dusty roads.
Her ranch is miles from the nearest big city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And then, when it seems as if you have walked for miles, you enter the magnificent Forum Romanum. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to be much better or more advanced than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Their product designs are miles ahead of the competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All sciences are miles ahead comparatively to the past, thanks to technology. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: relating to the army, navy, or air force
dictionaryExamples: military action/service
military uniform
military targets/forces
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During my military experience I worked in the kitchen, so kitchen work is quite normal for me as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a country's army, navy, and air force
dictionaryExamples: The military has opposed any cuts in defense spending.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Until the 1970s, fencing was a sport restricted to the military. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a white liquid produced by women and other female animals, such as cows
dictionaryExamples: a glass/carton of milk
cow's/goat's milk
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like [to] drink coffee and tea with milk. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a period of 1000 years
dictionaryExamples: We had a party to celebrate the new millennium.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the cusp of a new millennium, the importance of holidays in this modernized, stressful world [is] undeniable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a unit of length which is equal to 0.001 meters
dictionaryExamples: The ring has a width of three millimeters.

sense.def: the number 1,000,000
dictionaryExamples: She got eight million dollars for appearing in that film.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It costs about three million VietNam dong (VND). Key English Test; A2; Vietnamese

sense.def: very many or a lot
dictionaryExamples: I've seen that movie a million times.
I have millions of things to finish before we go on vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are millions of things you can do with a computer. (757634; First Certificate in English; Cyprus; B2 VANTAGE; 2000; Greek; Pass

sense.def: someone's memory or their ability to think, feel emotions, and be aware of things
dictionaryExamples: My mind was full of what had happened the night before, and I wasn't concentrating.
I just said the first thing that came into my mind.
For some reason her words stuck in my mind.
She has a very logical mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At my first class he asked to me sing a [song] in English, so I sang "Always on my mind!" Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to change a decision or opinion
dictionaryExamples: I've changed my mind about selling the house.
If you change your mind, let me know.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first I wasn't so excited as Clara, but after an afternoon there I changed my mind! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

blocks.phrase: make up your mind or make your mind up

sense.def: to make a decision
dictionaryExamples: I haven't made up my mind whether to apply for the job yet.
They couldn't make their minds up about where to go on vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The place was so dirty that I made up my mind to change it by buy[ing] something useful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to remember to consider someone or something that may be useful in the future
dictionaryExamples: I'll keep you in mind if another job comes up.
Bear in mind that there's a public holiday next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But we should keep in mind that books improve our vocabulary and, what's more, our imagination. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: If an idea crosses your mind, you think about it for a short time.
dictionaryExamples: It never crossed my mind that she might be married.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first thought that crossed his mind was to call the police immediately and that was what he actually did. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to wait until you know all the facts before you form an opinion about something or judge someone
dictionaryExamples: We're keeping an open mind about the causes of the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To listen, to communicate, [and] to have an open mind are a way of life [nowadays]. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to say something that will help someone to stop worrying
dictionaryExamples: I was worried about the test, but the nurse explained everything and put my mind at ease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To drive, even though only for 30 minutes, might give you confidence for the driving test and put your mind at ease. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to give your full attention to something and try very hard to do it
dictionaryExamples: You could win if you put your mind to it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With all the technology available, the task is actually quite simple if you put your mind to it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to have difficulty making a decision
dictionaryExamples: I was of  two minds about whether to invite him to the wedding.

sense.def: If something comes to mind, you think of it.
dictionaryExamples: I was thinking about who might be suitable for this job, and your name came to mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main problem that comes to mind concerning transportation within the city is the city road network. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If something blows your mind, you are very excited or surprised by it.
dictionaryExamples: There was one scene in the movie that really blew my mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "MOMO," written by Michael Ende, is a book that blew my mind as a child and as an adult, I have read it many times, but the last time has been a while now. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to think or worry about something
dictionaryExamples: Jim has a lot on his mind at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was just that I already had a lot on my mind and my cousin's daughters would surely d[i]stract me from studying. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If something springs to mind, you suddenly think of it.
dictionaryExamples: Mention fashion and Kate’s name immediately springs to mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A musical event that clearly springs to mind is a Rolling Stones concert in Parken, Copenhagen, which I attended in June 1998. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: in your imagination or memory
dictionaryExamples: In my mind's eye, I imagined the building painted white, with a beautiful garden around it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He sees her in his mind's eye, running around barefoot, laughing and squealing, wading in the water and running back out, screaming, trying to get away from the breaking waves. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to say exactly what you think without worrying if it will upset anyone
dictionaryExamples: She has very strong opinions and she's not afraid to speak her mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His father is even more eccentric, speaks his mind, and has no manners at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the way someone feels at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: She was in a much more positive frame of mind today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Naturally, these are more difficult factors to cope with for older people, but it just happens to anyone if you're not in the right frame of mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a feeling that you do not need to worry about anything
dictionaryExamples: For my peace of mind, please check that the door is locked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After all, successfully earning your living guarantees peace of mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the ability to deal with a difficult situation quickly and effectively
dictionaryExamples: She had the presence of mind to press the alarm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Frank tried to hide a bag behind his back with great presence of mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something slips your mind, you forget about it.
dictionaryExamples: I meant to tell her you had phoned, but it completely slipped my mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was something but it slipped my mind before I reached it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to try to remember
dictionaryExamples: If you cast your mind back, you might recall that I never promised to go.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, when I pick one of these stones, I cast my mind back to the specific place where I found it, the person I was, the particular moment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: something you say when politely asking if you can do something, or when asking someone else to do something
dictionaryExamples: Do you mind if  I turn the television on?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you mind if I bring a friend? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say the choice is not important when responding to an offer or suggestion
dictionaryExamples: "Would you like tea or coffee?" "I don't mind - either."
"Shall we take the train or go by bus?" "I don't mind which, you choose."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't mind what we do. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to tell someone not to worry about something because it is not important
dictionaryExamples: "I'm afraid I've lost that wallet you gave me." "Well, never mind, I can easily buy you another one."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Never mind Ally, forget it, I know you['ve] been busy. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to be annoyed, unhappy or worried by something
dictionaryExamples: Would she mind if I came too?
Take Juan's book - I'm sure he wouldn't mind.
I don't mind driving.
I don't mind taking her  if you're too busy.
Do you mind me smoking?
I'd prefer to stay in tonight, if you don't mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to borrow your bicycle if you don't mind because m[ine] doesn't work well. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: used to request something politely
dictionaryExamples: Would you mind sharing a room?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Would you mind if I called you, to know what I've missed? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to tell someone in that you are annoyed and they should not ask about something  private
dictionaryExamples: I wish you'd just mind your own business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite knowing that he was only doing what he thought was best for me, I couldn't stand him, and I often told him to mind his own business. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the things that belong or relate to the person who is speaking or writing
dictionaryExamples: "Whose bag is this?" "It's mine."
Your son is the same age as mine.
She's an old friend of mine.
Can I use your pen? Mine's not working.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A friend of mine gave me a present [o]n my birthday. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: an underground system of holes and passages where people dig out coal or other minerals
dictionaryExamples: a coal/salt/gold mine
My grandfather used to work down in the mines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a more or less industrial region with many co[al] mines. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: someone who works in a mine
dictionaryExamples: a coal miner
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are used to strikes in our country so when we heard that the miners had refused to work we did not despair. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: water which is taken from the ground and contains natural chemical substances
dictionaryExamples: still/carbonated mineral water
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: P.S. You can bring a bottle of mineral water. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: to meet and talk to other people in a place or at an event
dictionaryExamples: The party will be a good opportunity to mingle with the other students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I let them mingle with other children and surprisingly, I can see that they are [very] sociable and they know how to respect the rights of other people. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: to mix, or be mixed
dictionaryExamples: The smell of coffee mingled with fresh-baked bread.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The chill current of appro[a]ching winter mingled with a lingering warmth of summer so that the air became fresh and alive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: extremely small
dictionaryExamples: a miniature camera
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Behind him [was] piled the most awkward assortment of stuff I had ever seen: a miniature Eiffel Tower, a monocycle, a letter-box, three netted cages, an accord[i]on, and a bunch of other things wh[ose] name I couldn't even guess. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If something is in miniature, it is a very small copy of something else.
dictionaryExamples: a model of the ship in miniature
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thirdly a co-educational school is a society in miniature and it has many practical advantages. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: as small or as little as possible
dictionaryExamples: Damage to the building was minimal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Areas which are no[t] transited regularly (such as warehouses, restrooms, etc.) are to be kept in minimal lighting conditions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to make the amount of something that is unpleasant or not wanted as small as possible
dictionaryExamples: Airport staff are trying to minimize the inconvenience caused to passengers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Try to minimize your working time and spend more time with other people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: The minimum amount of something is the smallest amount that is allowed, needed, or possible.
dictionaryExamples: There is a minimum charge of $5 for postage.
Eighteen is the minimum age for entering most nightclubs.
That's the minimum degree required to teach English in most language schools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am going to phone them to ask how much the wage is, but anyway the minimum rate in England is £3.60. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the smallest amount that is allowed, needed, or possible
dictionaryExamples: The judge sentenced him to a minimum of five years in prison.
We need a minimum of ten people to play this game.
Wage increases are being kept to a minimum because of the recession.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should spend a minimum [of] 1-2 hours per day [on] this activity. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Thai

sense.def: the industry or activity of removing substances such as coal or metal from the ground by digging
dictionaryExamples: coal/salt mining
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My company deals mostly with the mining, processing and benefic[i]ation of magnesite ore. Most of our final products are sold abroad. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a member of the government in Britain and many other countries who is in charge of a particular department or has an important position in it
dictionaryExamples: the foreign/health minister
the Minister of/for Education
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was elected minister of sports, creating some laws to help the players to be more independent. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in some countries, a government department that is responsible for a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: the Ministry of Defense/Agriculture
a Foreign Ministry spokesman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to a majority of students, it's quite economical for them to go to state schools since the Turkish Ministry of Education gives them scholarships. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: not important or serious
dictionaryExamples: a minor offense/operation
She suffered only minor injuries.
It requires a few minor adjustments.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Happily they were found by some hunters and escaped with minor injuries. First Certificate in English; B2; Romanian

sense.def: less than half of a group of people or things
dictionaryExamples: Only a minority of people support the proposal.
Traditional families are in the minority in this neighborhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, the minority of people who believe the opposite maybe want to see the animals and to watch their movements. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a group of people who share some characteristic that is different from most of the people where they live
dictionaryExamples: ethnic/religious minorities
The plan was designed to help women and minorities overcome discrimination in the workplace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The novel reveals very clearly to the reader how minorities are exploited and scorned by society. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a herb whose leaves have a strong fresh smell and taste and are used for giving flavor to food and drinks such as tea
dictionaryExamples: a bunch of mint
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd recommend his special lamb chop with mint sauce, it's just so delicious. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: reduced by a stated number
dictionaryExamples: Five minus three is two.
That will be $1500, minus the deposit of $150 that you have already paid.
The temperature fell to minus 20 overnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's cold [in] winter: minus ten degrees! Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: a period of time equal to 60 seconds
dictionaryExamples: a ten-minute bus ride
It takes me twenty minutes to get to work.
The train leaves at three minutes to eight, so we'd better get there a few minutes before then.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a break for 20 minutes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: a very short period of time
dictionaryExamples: I'll be with you in a minute.
It'll only take a minute to call him.
When you've got a minute, I'd like a brief word with you.
Hang on a minute - I'll be with you as soon as I can!
Can you hold on a minute - he's on the other side of the yard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Without losing [a] minute I packed my things and I took a cab home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: said in order to interrupt someone, or to get their attention or when you have suddenly thought of something important
dictionaryExamples: Wait a minute - I've just had an idea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oh! Wait a minute... First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: very soon
dictionaryExamples: Her train should be arriving any minute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The evil creatures who were bound to come out of the dark [w]ould see Carla any minute now. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the latest time possible
dictionaryExamples: The concert was canceled at the last minute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were very disappointed to hear that the actor was replaced by [an]other at the last minute. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: as soon as
dictionaryExamples: I'll tell you the minute we hear any news.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even when we are small babies, from the minute that we are able to understand what is happening around us, the first thing that we do is try to learn and touch everything that is close to us and get familiar with it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: extremely small
dictionaryExamples: a minute amount/quantity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I see no sense in having a supermarket, an ugly and gigantic block, next to a village where the inhabitants only require a minute amount of food, since we are all self-sustaining because of our farms. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: done in great detail
dictionaryExamples: He explained everything in minute detail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is also a person who can pay meticulous attention to minute details. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: something that is very surprising or difficult to believe
dictionaryExamples: an economic miracle
Looking at the state of his car, it's a miracle (that) he wasn't killed.
I can't promise a miracle cure, but I think we can improve things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every single day we hear about new products, new methods, new technological miracles which have turned our daily lives [upside down]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of glass with a shiny metallic material on one side which produces an image of anything that is in front of it
dictionaryExamples: the bathroom mirror
She was looking at her reflection in the mirror.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The mirror was given to me by Jenny. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to behave badly
dictionaryExamples: If you misbehave, you will be punished - it's as simple as that.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, an apology is due to all nearby residents whose lives were disturbed by a few somewhat misbehaving students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: sad
dictionaryExamples: I just woke up feeling miserable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I feel very miserable and my boyfriend is still angry with me because that ring was his gift for our first year together. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: very unpleasant or bad, and causing someone to feel unhappy
dictionaryExamples: miserable weather
Families here are living in miserable conditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Heathcliff [always swears revenge because of] the miserable situation the other character[s] have put him in. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: great suffering or unhappiness
dictionaryExamples: The war brought misery to millions of people.
We have witnessed the most appalling scenes of human misery.
Ten years of marriage to him have made her life a misery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] few hours of amusement for us might mean a whole life of misery for the animals. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: bad luck, or an unlucky event
dictionaryExamples: He had the misfortune to fall in love with a married woman.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But try not to wear black because they believe it brings bad luck and misfortune. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: an accident or unlucky event which usually is not serious
dictionaryExamples: They suffered a series of mishaps during the trip.
The accident was just a tragic mishap.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally speaking, I have always received courteous attention from my parents and this has helped me overcome all mishaps that may occur. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to give someone false information
dictionaryExamples: I'm afraid you've been misinformed about your test results.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the article, I got the impression that your reporter was misinformed about certain facts which are crucial for a better [understanding] of the event. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to understand something in the wrong way
dictionaryExamples: He claims his speech was deliberately misinterpreted by journalists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A direct consequence of this is that adults misinterpret their intentions and object to youth's lack of respect. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when something is understood in the wrong way
dictionaryExamples: What he said was a complete misinterpretation of my views.
If doctors don't know all your symptoms, it can lead to misinterpretations of your illness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As written in the letter, which I hope you have received from my friend, I worked with in this organi[z]ation, we want to inform you of the true version in order to avoid misinterpretations and misunderstandings. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to make someone believe something that is untrue by giving them information that is wrong or not complete
dictionaryExamples: She claims the public was misled by the government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to point out that some information in the article was wrong, which could mislead your readers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: making someone believe something that is untrue
dictionaryExamples: misleading information/statements
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found it rather misleading and I would like to provide true information about the festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to lose something temporarily by forgetting where you have put it
dictionaryExamples: I seem to have misplaced my keys.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is only when these possessions are lost or stolen or simply misplaced that they are greatly missed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a title for a girl or woman who is not married, used before her family name or full name
dictionaryExamples: Dr. White will see you now, Miss Carter.
Miss Helena Lewis
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Miss Timson, How are you? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: to not go to something
dictionaryExamples: You'll fall behind in your studies if you keep missing school.
I missed my class this morning.
He missed the office party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You only missed the best party of the year! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to feel sad about someone that you do not see now or something that you do not have or do now
dictionaryExamples: I really missed her when she went away.
She will be sadly missed by all who knew her.
I still miss my old car.
What did you miss most about England when you were living in France?
I really miss cycling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I miss you a lot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to arrive too late to get on a bus, train, aircraft, etc.
dictionaryExamples: You'll miss your train if you don't hurry up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if we missed the train, I was happy and this was the most important thing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to not use an opportunity to do something
dictionaryExamples: You can't afford to miss a chance like this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It's] the most important tennis competi[t]ion in my town, and I can't miss this opportunity. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to avoid doing or experiencing something
dictionaryExamples: You should leave early if you want to miss the rush hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want to have [a] nice time, you [should] leave the hotel early in the morning because in this way you [will] miss the rush-hour traffic. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to not see or hear something
dictionaryExamples: Sorry, I missed that, could you repeat it please?
We missed the first five minutes of the movie.
My office is first on the right with a bright red door. You can't miss it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, the Festival began on time at midday with King Cup. Maybe you might have missed that part. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to fail to do something at the correct time or to be too late to do something or see something or someone
dictionaryExamples: I wanted to see that movie but I missed it.
Helen?  I'm sorry, you just missed her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I missed the dinner I was going to have with my best friend in London. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to not hit or catch something as you intended
dictionaryExamples: It should have been such an easy goal and he missed.
He threw a book at me, but it missed.
The bullet missed his heart by a couple of centimeters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He aimed for the heart, and, when he was about to fire, an innocent pigeon landed on his rifle. Paul wasn't expecting this, and his shot missed the judge. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to be too late to do or get something
dictionaryExamples: I'm afraid you've missed the boat. The concert tickets have sold out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What if she never had another chance?  What if she missed the boat? Overcome by the anxiety and the lack of sleep, the first thing she did in the morning was to pick up two of her best poems [and] put them in an envelope. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to not do or have something that you would enjoy or something that other people do or have
dictionaryExamples: I got to the party too late and missed out on all the fun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They don't know what they are missing out on. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: an explosive weapon which can travel long distances through the air
dictionaryExamples: nuclear missiles
a missile attack
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the meantime dissident elements of the terrorist organization had tried to make contact with the United States intelligence organizations to warn them of possible bomb or missile attacks on their Kenyan and Tanzanian missions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If someone or something is missing, you cannot find them because they are not in their usual place.
dictionaryExamples: Her father has been missing since September 1992.
One of my blue socks is missing.
Have you found those missing documents?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday, when I reached home, I found that my note book was missing. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: not included in something
dictionaryExamples: There are a couple of names missing from the list.
When did you realize that the money was missing from your account?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But even with all this furniture, I feel like there is something missing, so I have decided to buy some posters of my favorite rock bands and put them [o]n the walls. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone's duty or purpose in life
dictionaryExamples: Her mission in life was to help the poor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You think that you are "great," since you can cope with both the job and lots of other "missions" in life, education, sports and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: an important job, usually traveling somewhere
dictionaryExamples: I'll be going on a fact-finding mission to Paris next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apparently somebody had tried to sabotage the mission and given them both different code words. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: small drops of water in the air which make it difficult to see objects which are not near
dictionaryExamples: The early-morning mist soon lifted/cleared.
The mountain villages seem to be permanently covered in mist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The mist was getting thicker all the time and the rain was coming down harder. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: something that you do or think that is wrong
dictionaryExamples: He made a lot of mistakes in his written test.
This letter's full of spelling mistakes.
We shouldn't have come here - it was a mistake.
It would be a big mistake to quit school.
She made the mistake of giving him her phone number.
I've discovered a few mistakes in your calculations.
I'm not blaming you - we all make mistakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You might need a[n] [eraser] if you make a mistake. Key English Test; A2; Korean

sense.def: If you do something by mistake, you do it without intending to.
dictionaryExamples: I picked up someone else's book by mistake.
I've paid this bill twice by mistake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A]fter 30 minutes, a man appeared telling [us] that he had taken our suitcases by mistake. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If you are mistaken, or you have a mistaken belief, you are wrong about something.
dictionaryExamples: If you think you can behave like that, you are mistaken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, you mentioned in the article that we promised 45 stalls for that day, but you are completely mistaken as we announced only 35. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: If the weather is misty, there is a cloud of small drops of water in the air, which makes it difficult to see objects that are not near.
dictionaryExamples: a cold and misty morning
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the evenings were a bit cold and misty. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: to not understand someone or something correctly
dictionaryExamples: He misunderstood the question completely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He meant that he had misunderstood the situation. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If someone is misunderstood, other people do not understand that they have good qualities.
dictionaryExamples: He was a genius, but misunderstood by society at the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was misunderstood by the adult world, he only wanted to be away from everybody, he wanted to be all by himself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when someone does not understand something correctly
dictionaryExamples: There must have been a misunderstanding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suppose there was a misunderstanding, because he told me on the phone that he had arranged with you to come next week. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to use something in the wrong way or for the wrong purpose
dictionaryExamples: He misused his position to obtain money dishonestly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By doing this the money won't be misused because we won't have to build a new indoor court that will not be used at all times. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the use of something in the wrong way or for the wrong purpose
dictionaryExamples: They accused him of misuse of power.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can we disregard the consequences there may be of the misuse of the above innovations of technology? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If two or more substances mix, they combine to make one substance, and if you mix two or more substances, you combine them to make one substance.
dictionaryExamples: Oil and water don't mix.
Mix the powder with water to form a paste.
In a large bowl, mix together the flour, sugar and raisins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can work at the bar mixing drinks. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: to have two or more qualities, or to do two or more activities, etc. at the same time
dictionaryExamples: a feeling of anger mixed with sadness
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That also could be a good way to mix learning and ent[ertai]nment. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to meet and talk to people
dictionaryExamples: She enjoys going to parties and mixing with people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like mixing with people. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

blocks.phrasalVerb: mix up sb/sth or mix sb/sth up

sense.def: to confuse two people or things by thinking that one person or thing is the other person or thing
dictionaryExamples: People often mix up the sisters because they look so similar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My role was to arrange all the cables for the light and sound, and now we are talking cables of about the length of 100 m each. I'd really had a lot to do not to get them mixed up. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a combination of things or people, often in a group
dictionaryExamples: There's a good mix of nationalities in the class.
There was an odd mix of people at Patrick's party.
"She's studying physics and philosophy." "That's an interesting mix."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This film is a mix of fantasy and adventure. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: a substance made of other substances that have been combined
dictionaryExamples: The mixture of flour, water and yeast is then left in a warm place for four hours.
Add milk to the mixture and stir until smooth.

sense.def: when there is a combination of two or more ideas, qualities, styles, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Their house is decorated in a mixture of styles.
Their latest CD is a mixture of new and old songs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The result is a very strange mixture of different styles. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to make a low sound, especially because you are in pain
dictionaryExamples: She lay on the floor moaning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He moaned and groaned but he did not have any obvious signs of injuries. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to complain or speak in a way that shows you are unhappy
dictionaryExamples: He's always moaning about something.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had been moaning all week about her job and her difficulties with this and that, but she couldn't remember having asked even once how Simon was getting [along]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a verb, for example "can," "might" or "must," that is used before another verb to show that something is possible, necessary, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The first verb in the following sentence is a modal: We ought to pay the gas bill.

sense.def: a way of doing something
dictionaryExamples: a mode of transport
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I think that both modes of education play a great role in educating children to be good members of society. International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a design of machine or car that is made by a particular company
dictionaryExamples: a luxury/new model
the latest model
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it very much, because it is the latest model and nobody at our school ha[s] it. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: a smaller copy of a real object, often used to show how something works or what it looks like
dictionaryExamples: a model of the railroad
By looking at this model you can get a better idea of how the bridge will look.
a plastic model aircraft
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm good at making models and telling stories. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: someone whose job is to wear fashionable clothes, be in photographs, etc., in order to advertise things
dictionaryExamples: a fashion model
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the future I hope to be a cloth[es] designer or a top model. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: someone or something that is an example for others to copy
dictionaryExamples: Their educational system was a model for other countries.
She was a model  student.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a "model" citizen of the Fahrenheit 451 society: she doesn't ask questions, she doesn't think by herself, either. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: average in size or amount and not too much
dictionaryExamples: a moderate income
The company was of moderate size, with about 50 employees.
Eating a moderate amount of fat is healthy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to eat healthy food and in moderate quantities, and to do our daily exerci[s]es. International English Language Testing System; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to make something less extreme
dictionaryExamples: He's trying to moderate his drinking.

sense.def: to a degree that is average but not very great
dictionaryExamples: There's very little moderately priced housing in this area.
The company remains moderately profitable, but it is not making as much money as it should.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Very often a moderately well-off person would take his chance and try to change his life, hopefully for [the] better. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: using the newest ideas, design, technology, etc. and not traditional
dictionaryExamples: modern architecture/art/medicine
We're in the very modern-looking building opposite the station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am going to use the green [paint]. I think it looks very modern. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: relating to the present time and not to the past
dictionaryExamples: modern society
the stresses of modern life
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll see the modern Japan. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: not large in size or amount, or not expensive or important
dictionaryExamples: a modest amount of money
They live in a fairly modest house, considering their wealth.
There has been a modest improvement in housing conditions for the poor.
The party made modest gains in the elections, but nothing like the huge gains that were predicted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is an honour for us to receive such a well-known writer in our modest school. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you are modest, you do not talk in a proud way about your skills or successes.
dictionaryExamples: He's very modest about his achievements.
Although an outstanding scientist, he’s a modest man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Earning a lot she is still very modest and does not show any signs of vanity at all. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: by a small size or amount
dictionaryExamples: At just £9, the DVD is very modestly priced.

sense.def: in a quiet way that does not show off your abilities, wealth, success, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She spoke modestly about her work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of them extravagantly and some modestly, depending on the status, importance and financial affordability of the people getting married. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: a small change to something
dictionaryExamples: We've made a few modifications to the system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I am very happy with the current design of my house I may make some modifications in the future. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to change something in order to improve it
dictionaryExamples: The plans will have to be modified to reduce costs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, the Work Experience in Britain program should be modified as it was a far cry from what we ha[d] been led to expect. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a mother
dictionaryExamples: I miss my mom and dad a lot.
Aw, Mom, why can't I go?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is very important for me because my mom gave it to me for my birthday last year. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: the continuing progress, motion, development, etc., that a person or thing is experiencing
dictionaryExamples: A falling object gains momentum as it falls.
The players began to lose momentum halfway through the game.
Technology seems to create its own momentum – if something can be done, it will be.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mr. Emerson strongly believes in social equality, and his views can be regarded as the reflection of the democratic movements gaining momentum at the beginning of our century. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the day of the week after Sunday and before Tuesday
dictionaryExamples: I start my new job on Monday.
I saw her last Monday.

We leave 
                      next Monday.
I was born on a Monday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He goes to school Monday and Friday. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kashmiri

sense.def: relating to money
dictionaryExamples: monetary policy
The monetary unit of the UK is the pound.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed such a country, [by] accepting tourists, [can] exchange its probably weak currency with potentially hard currencies of strong monetary value, and help its economy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the coins or bills  that are used to buy things
dictionaryExamples: How much money do you have?
I don't have much money on me.
I spent a lot of money.
Roger wanted to buy it but it cost too much money.

The company isn't making 
                          any money this year.
Try to save  some money for your vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is from England and he is very friendly and he  work[s] a lot because he likes money. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Amharic

sense.def: a screen that shows information or pictures, usually connected to a computer
dictionaryExamples: I bought a bigger monitor for my computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We know our world from TV screens and computer monitors. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: someone whose job is to watch or check something
dictionaryExamples: a class/school monitor
United Nations monitors were allowed to enter the area.
an election monitor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Wednesday [the] 13th I'll be a monitor in a studying group (it's a task due to my scholarship). First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to watch and check someone or something carefully over a period of time
dictionaryExamples: to monitor progress
The nurse is monitoring his heart rate and respiration.
They hired an accountant to help monitor cash flow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I said before, a close and personalized monitoring of the child (particularly when young) is very important, and the only way to do this is to reduce the number of students per class. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a hairy animal with a long tail that lives in hot countries and climbs trees
dictionaryExamples: Of all the animals at the zoo he liked the monkeys best.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can see animals like monkeys [and] birds, you can feed the fishes and also have a great meal at the restaurant. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: control by a company or group over all of a type of business or activity
dictionaryExamples: The Postal Service is guaranteed a monopoly on all first-class letters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, it is quite obvious that the reason why a second supermarket is planned in our area is related to the current monopoly of the first supermarket. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If something is monotonous, it is boring because it stays the same.
dictionaryExamples: a monotonous voice
monotonous work
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The voice of the speaker is monotonous and lacks any rhythm or modulation, intrinsic parts of any language without which proper acquisition of it is impossible. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: an imaginary creature that is large, ugly, and frightening
dictionaryExamples: a sea monster
the Loch Ness monster
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a cartoon, telling [a] story about a monster, Stitch, who change[d] the life of a little girl called Lilo. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a cruel and frightening person
dictionaryExamples: To the whole world, he was a monster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In her opinion he was a monster without any human feelings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish
