sense.def: one of the twelve periods of time that a year is divided into
dictionaryExamples: February is the shortest month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need [to] ask you, if I can star[t] this course next month, [i]n January, and finish in June. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: a period of approximately four weeks
dictionaryExamples: She'll be working here for six months.
I saw him about three months ago.
a two-month-old puppy
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My boy friend and I visit every winter for 3-4 month[s]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: happening or produced once a month
dictionaryExamples: monthly payments
a monthly magazine
We're paid monthly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the moment I pay £550 monthly plus bills. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Spanish

sense.def: an old building or place that is important in history
dictionaryExamples: an ancient monument
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In these cities you will be able to visit ancient monuments. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a structure that is built to make people remember an event in history or a famous person
dictionaryExamples: In the square in front of the hotel stands a monument to all the people killed in the war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First I went to see the Larienki Park and admired the beautiful monument [to] the greatest Polish composer - Chopin. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the way you feel at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: She's in a bad mood.
You're in a good mood today.
What sort of mood is Ted in today?
Her mood seemed to change during the course of the conversation.
The public mood changed dramatically after the bombing.
The mood of the crowd suddenly turned  aggressive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I reckon I was in a bad mood, but nothing had happened to end o[u]r relationship. Preliminary English Test; B1; Wolof

sense.def: to not be friendly to other people because you are feeling angry
dictionaryExamples: Ignore him - he's in a mood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't mind the rain, actually I prefer rain when I am in a mood like that. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

blocks.phrase: be in the mood for sth/to do sth

sense.def: to want to do or have something
dictionaryExamples: I'm not really in the mood for shopping at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should you be in the mood for a walk around the lake then go for it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: light that comes from the moon
dictionaryExamples: In the moonlight, she looked even more beautiful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The floor was dark, [and] the moonlight which came through the window gave the only light. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: relating to beliefs about what is right or wrong
dictionaryExamples: moral values
a moral issue
It’s her moral obligation to tell the police what she knows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her ideas and her moral values are pure, conveyed clearly and imparted to young children in spite of their lively jauntiness. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: behaving in ways considered by most people to be correct and honest
dictionaryExamples: He's a highly moral man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Taking into account all these matters, we can see a moral, brave man fighting for his country and for what he believes in. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a lesson that can be learned from a story or event
dictionaryExamples: The moral of the story is never lie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The hidden moral she's trying to tell me is that I'll have to do everything by myself. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: standards for good behavior
dictionaryExamples: He has no morals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Without limits, without morals, a child cannot build his own personality. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the amount of confidence or hope for the future that people feel
dictionaryExamples: The increase in pay should help to improve staff morale.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Recent events have caused the morale of the troops to disintegrate completely. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: in a moral way
dictionaryExamples: morally wrong/unacceptable
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Doesn't it seems morally wrong? Animals need their space and natural surroundings to survive. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: something in addition to what you already have
dictionaryExamples: Would you like some more food?
There isn't enough milk - I'll have to buy some more.
I need a bit more time.
The doctors can't cope with any more patients.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now [I] have more free time, I and my family go to [the] swimming pool. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a greater number or amount of people or things
dictionaryExamples: There are more people here today than yesterday.
He knows more about dogs than I do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In [the] disco I can meet more new people. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: If you do not do something or something does not happen any more, you have stopped doing it or it does not now happen.
dictionaryExamples: I don't do yoga any more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't need it any more because I have a new one. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: one more time
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to visit the colleges once more before we leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Friday I will see him once more. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an increasing number
dictionaryExamples: More and more people are choosing not to buy a car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More and more youngsters have problems with reading and writing. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used before an adjective or adverb to show that someone or something has a greater amount of a quality than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: This exercise is more difficult than the last one.
It's more expensive than the others.
Could you read a bit more slowly, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This place is more beautiful than Stratford. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: used to show that something happens a greater number of times than before
dictionaryExamples: We eat out a lot more than we used to.
We go to the movies more often in the winter.

 Key English Test; A2; Italian

Tom's my older son.
It wasn't my fault.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my class, where [there are] about 15 people, I [am] learning very interesting things. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: the reflexive form of the pronouns "me" or "I"
dictionaryExamples: I've bought myself a new coat.
I caught sight of myself in the mirror.
Yes, I thought to myself, it's time to take a vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoyed myself a lot. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: alone or without anyone's help
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't carry all the luggage by myself.
I spent the night all by myself.
I made this chair myself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to paint my bedroom, but it [is] hard for me to do this by myself. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: used to emphasize "I" as the subject of a sentence
dictionaryExamples: I myself don't like a heavy meal at lunchtime.
I'll tell her myself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear editor of 'The Student Tourist Guidebook' [I am writing] regard[ing] your latest student tourist guidebook, which I myself found very useful on my latest trip to Lampton. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: for my use only
dictionaryExamples: I'll have the house all to myself this weekend.
I need a couple of hours to myself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is because if I live[d] in a triple-storey [house], I would get a room all to myself. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: strange or unknown, and not explained or understood
dictionaryExamples: a mysterious stranger
the mysterious death of her son
He died in mysterious circumstances, and there is still a possibility that it was murder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He went to the Hotel because he wanted to find out who was the person that had sent him a mysterious letter a few days ago. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in a way that is mysterious
dictionaryExamples: "Perhaps, and perhaps not," she said mysteriously.
Mysteriously, the light came on, although no one was near the switch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mysteriously, their character always dies tragically or goes abroad and [is] never seen again. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: something strange or unknown which has not yet been explained or understood
dictionaryExamples: an unsolved mystery
How the massive stones were brought here from hundreds of miles away remains a mystery.
He never gave up hope that he would solve the mystery of his son's disappearance.
He's out of work, so how he pays his rent is a mystery to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have chosen this film because it has mystery in it and a lot of fun!! Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: an ancient story about gods and brave people, often one that explains an event in history or the natural world
dictionaryExamples: ancient myths
the gods and goddesses of Greek and Roman myth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I spent three days there thinking about myths and legends and having a lot of fun. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an idea that is not true but is believed by many people
dictionaryExamples: Equal opportunity continues to be a myth for many.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is this myth that when you are on vacation you should spend your whole time at the beach, practically doing nothing. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek
